attributes.title: Playing the Blame Game: Chief Executives, Legislative Success, and Reelection

q1.value: Playing the Blame Game: Chief Executives, Legislative Success, and Reelection

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The goal of this project is to understand whether voters are more likely to vote for candidates for chief executive office when those candidates have a history of bipartisan policymaking leadership. It will answer the following questions. Do voters reward candidates for bipartisan leadership? Can bipartisanship improve a candidate's reelection probability even when the candidate loses a vote on their proposal? Lastly, do opposition parties receive backlash from voters for obstructing the chief executive's proposal?

q16.value: "1. Voters are more likely to support candidates for chief executive office when those candidates have a record of bipartisan policymaking leadership on a proposal. 2. Hypothesis 1 holds even when the candidate loses the vote on their program. 3. The opposition party receives less blame for the outcome of the chief executive's proposal than the chief executive."

q17.value: "I will conduct a survey experiment. I will provide respondents with a vignette about a piece of legislation in a hypothetical state. Respondents will learn that the legislation is popular among the state’s citizens and that the governor supports it. Then, they will randomly learn either that the bill passed or failed with bipartisan support or without bipartisan support. There will be three treatments where the governor wins and three where he loses. In the three that he wins, his party will have a majority in the legislature. In the three that he loses, his party will have a minority in the legislature. After respondents read the vignette, I will ask them (1) how likely they are to vote for the governor in the next election and (2) how likely they are to vote for legislative candidates of the two parties in the next election. Although I am primarily interested in how they evaluate the opposition party, I want to avoid signaling this to respondents so I will ask about both parties. Below is a template for the question. (respondents will receive one of the vignettes and one of the vote outcomes) Imagine you are a citizen of an American state in which the governor’s party has 60 seats in the state’s legislature, and the opposition party has 40 seats. The governor has proposed to give teachers a bonus if their students score higher on a nationwide standardized test. A recent public opinion poll found that 68% of voters support this proposal and 32% oppose it. The legislature passed the governor’s proposal, and the votes were as follows: Yes No Yes No Governor’s Party 60 0 Governor’s Party 60 0 Opposition Party 0 40 Opposition Party 20 20 Total 60 40 Total 80 20 Yes No Governor’s Party 60 0 Opposition Party 40 0 Total 100 0 Imagine you are a citizen of an American state in which the governor’s party has 40 seats in the state’s legislature, and the opposition party has 60 seats. The governor has proposed to give teachers a bonus if their students score higher on a nationwide standardized test. A recent public opinion poll found that 68% of voters support this proposal and 32% oppose it. The legislature rejected the governor’s proposal, and the votes were as follows: Yes No Yes No Governor’s Party 40 0 Governor’s Party 40 0 Opposition Party 0 60 Opposition Party 5 55 Total 40 60 Total 45 55 Yes No Governor’s Party 40 0 Opposition Party 9 51 Total 49 51 We are interested in how likely you would be to vote for the governor’s reelection. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all likely and 10 is very likely, how likely would you be to vote for the governor? We are also interested in how likely you would be to vote for legislative candidates of the two parties. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all likely and 10 is very likely, how likely would you be to vote for the governor’s party’s legislative candidates? On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all likely and 10 is very likely, how likely would you be to vote for the opposition party’s legislative candidates? I plan to have all of these questions visible on the same page so that respondents know they have to rate both the governor and the legislature. After the treatment question, respondents will be asked demographic questions about their party affiliation, gender, age, education, and ethnicity. These will be used to check for heterogeneous treatment effects, though none are expected. I plan to have around 500 respondents per treatment group for a total of 3,000 respondents in the experiment. Before the full scale experiment, I will pilot it with a smaller number of respondents."

The governor has proposed to give teachers a bonus if their students score higher on a nationwide standardized test. A recent public opinion poll found that 68% of voters support this proposal and 32% oppose it. The legislature rejected the governor’s proposal, and the votes were as follows: Yes No Yes No Governor’s Party 40 0 Governor’s Party 40 0 Opposition Party 0 60 Opposition Party 5 55 Total 40 60 Total 45 55 Yes No Governor’s Party 40 0 Opposition Party 9 51 Total 49 51 We are interested in how likely you would be to vote for the governor’s reelection. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all likely and 10 is very likely, how likely would you be to vote for the governor? We are also interested in how likely you would be to vote for legislative candidates of the two parties. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all likely and 10 is very likely, how likely would you be to vote for the governor’s party’s legislative candidates? On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all likely and 10 is very likely, how likely would you be to vote for the opposition party’s legislative candidates? I plan to have all of these questions visible on the same page so that respondents know they have to rate both the governor and the legislature. After the treatment question, respondents will be asked demographic questions about their party affiliation, gender, age, education, and ethnicity. These will be used to check for heterogeneous treatment effects, though none are expected. I plan to have around 500 respondents per treatment group for a total of 3,000 respondents in the experiment. Before the full scale experiment, I will pilot it with a smaller number of respondents."

attributes.title: Palliative care of hematological cancer
attributes.description: Retrospective registry study comparing palliative care of patients with hematological malignancies to other cancer patients

q1.value: Palliative care of patients with hematological malignancies

q3.value: Patients with hematological malignancies have been shown to receive more active treatment late in the disease, and to be less likely to be referred to hospice care, than patients with solid tumours. In this study, I will use the Swedish palliative care registry to see if this can be verified in swedish patients, if patients with hematological malignancies are less likely to receive high-quality palliative care than patients with solid tumours and if there are indications that this impact the quality of life during end of life for these patients.

q4.value:
My hypothesis is that patients with hematological malignancies (and their next of kin) are less likely to receive information about transition to end-of-life care and that they are more likely to die in a hospital instead of in specialised palliative care or in their homes, as compared to patients with solid tumours. 
This could be associated with other indicators of lower quality palliative care, such as higher probability of receiving iv fluids during the last days of life, lower probability of having prescriptions of palliative drugs and lower probability of relatives being offered follow-up after the death of the patient. 
If so, this might increase the frequency of symtoms in the last days of life, especially anxiety, in the patients. This could also lead to a higher probability of the nursing staff experiencing discontent with the care given to the patient.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Blinding is not applicable as this is a retrospective registry study

question.value: Retrospective, registry-based study on patients registered in the Swedish palliative care registry. Study group: Patients, age >=18, cause of death registered as hematological malignancy (ICD C81-C96). Compare group: Patients, age >=18, cause of death registered as malignancy (ICD C00-C97), excluding hematological malignancy as above.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The data is collected in the Swedish Register of Palliative Care (SRPC). I have made a request for data extraction for the purpose of this study, but has not accessed the data before registering the study.

question.value:
Data is entered in the Swedish Register of Palliative Care (SRPC) using an end-of-life questionnaire (see attached file), filled out by the health care personnel caring for the patients. Cause of death is drawn from the register of cause of death, held by the National Board of Health and Welfare in Sweden.
The data requested from the registry were the answers to question 6-11 and 16-26 of the questionnaire.

q13.value: All patients included in the SRPC from 2011-01-01 to 2016-12-31, with "cancer" entered as cause of death.

q14.value: Data during this time period includes cause of death by ICD-code drawn from the cause of death registry held by the National Board of Helath and Welfare.

question.value:
Age, sex and cause of death by ICD-code. 
Answers to questions 6-11 and 16-26 of the end-of-life questionnaire.
For question 26, which is answered on a scale from 1-5, the answers will be dichotomised as 1-2 (=discontent) vs 3-5 (content).

Logistical regression adjusting for age and sex. 
Hematological malignancy vs other malignancy for main comparison on each individual variable. 
Main analysis will only include patients with the answer "yes" to question 8 (was the death expected?). If there is a significant difference between the groups in the frequency of "don't know"-answers, the "don't know"-group will also be analysed separately.
Sub-group analysis: Patients dying in hospital and patients dying in specialised palliative care will be analysed separately. 
Within the patients with hematological malignancies, comparisons will be made between patients with multiple myeloma (C90.0) and acute leukemia (C91.0, C92.0, C95.0)

q21.value: P-value of <0,05 will be considered significant. No correction will be made for multiple comparisons as the variables are not independent, but if only one single variable is significantly different this will be considered a chance finding.

attributes.title: Does Spatial Segregation Directly Facilitate the Attribution of Negative Stereotypes?

q1.value: Does Spatial Segregation Directly Facilitate the Attribution of Negative Stereotypes?

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: "Residential segregation has repeatedly been shown to correlate with unharmonious attitudes and behaviors between social groups (see Uslaner 2012). This is commonly attributed to segregation decreasing intergroup contact. Intergroup contact has long been theorized to reduce intergroup prejudice (Allport 1954). In this experiment, I follow on my previous research (Enos 2011) to test whether segregation has a direct effect, independent of intergroup contact, on intergroup prejudice. Spatial segregation may cause people to perceive members of groups to be more distinct from members of other groups than they would without segregation. This is because space is a fundamental part of human cognition and humans are usually aware of where other groups of people live. Humans use space to make judgments about the world. With these two processes, spatial separation may facilitate categorization, which has been shown to facilitate perceptions of difference between groups (Tajfel and Wilkes 1963). I have demonstrated this process in previous research, using abstract objects and images of people (Enos 2011). In this test, I go one step further to test whether segregation will facilitate the application of culturally specific stereotypes to groups. If segregation allows for groups to be more easily categorized, than stereotypes associated with these categories should be more readily applied."

q16.value: I will test whether segregation increases differences in the attribution of intelligence to whites and blacks. My hypothesis is that, compared to an integrated condition, subjects will perceive faces as less intelligent when segregated with Black faces and more intelligent with segregated with whites faces.

q17.value: "Subjects will be recruited using Amazon Mechanical Turk and Harvard DLABSS. Subjects will be exposed to a series of images with white and black faces on the screen and one highlighted face that is a morphed photo from a white and African American person. After being exposed to an image for 5 seconds, they will be asked to rate the intelligence of the highlighted face on a seven point scale. Subjects are exposed to two conditions: integrated and segregated. Within the segregated condition, they will be randomly exposed to one of two conditions: 1) segregated with the highlighted face grouped with black faces, 2) segregated with the highlighted face grouped with white faces. The ordering of display is as follows: 1) subjects are randomized into integrated or segregated, black or white, and see the appropriate image; 2) subjects are shown 24 distractor tasks with other faces highlighted. 3) subjects see the image, either integrated or segregated that they did not see in step 1. This means a subject sees the same face integrated and segregated, either with white or black faces. To test for the effect of segregation, a within-subject difference is obtained for the difference in responses on the 7-point scale for the segregated and integrated conditions. This difference is obtained separately for subjects in the white segregated condition and subjects in the black segregated condition. In the white segregated condition, subjects are expected to attribute more intelligence to the face in the segregated condition (positive differences). In the black segregated condition, subjects are expected to attribute less intelligence in the integrated condition (negative differences). I will conduct a T-test for difference of means between subjects will be conducted for white segregated minus white integrated and black segregated minus black integrated. The difference in means is expected to be significantly different than zero. I will subset the data in the following manner: 1) Data will be subset to subjects to the inner-90th percentile range of time on the task because too little time or too much time can indicate respondents clicking randomly or leaving the browser open and not completing the task. 2) Data will be subset to whites in the United States, since other groups may be less willing to attribute these stereotypes. 3) Data will be subset to male respondents because men are most likely to have ethnocentric tendencies."

registration_responses.q1: Does Spatial Segregation Directly Facilitate the Attribution of Negative Stereotypes?

Spatial segregation may cause people to perceive members of groups to be more distinct from members of other groups than they would without segregation. This is because space is a fundamental part of human cognition and humans are usually aware of where other groups of people live. Humans use space to make judgments about the world. With these two processes, spatial separation may facilitate categorization, which has been shown to facilitate perceptions of difference between groups (Tajfel and Wilkes 1963). I have demonstrated this process in previous research, using abstract objects and images of people (Enos 2011). In this test, I go one step further to test whether segregation will facilitate the application of culturally specific stereotypes to groups. If segregation allows for groups to be more easily categorized, than stereotypes associated with these categories should be more readily applied."

attributes.title: Income Inequality and Counterfeits - Egalitarian Motives

q1.value: iPhone GooPhone mixed design HBS with Egalitarian Motives

q2.value: S. Wiley Wakeman, Jingshi Liu, Michael I Norton

q3.value: In this study, we test how perceived income inequality affects people's perceptions of a genuine vs. a counterfeit phone.

q4.value: Under high (vs. low) income inequality, consumers are more likely to perceive counterfeit (vs. genuine) products to have greater egalitarian value. The egalitarian value in turn positively affects consumers' attitudes toward counterfeits. The effect of egalitarian value on counterfeit attitudes should be independent of the hedonic, utilitarian, status signaling, and economic values of a counterfeit.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 between-subject (video: income inequality, neutral) X 2 within-subject (phone: counterfeit, genuine) mixed design

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the 2 (video: income inequality, neutral). In the income inequality condition, they watch a video about wealth inequality in the US. In the neutral video, they watch a video about brain science.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will post the study on MTurk. Participants will receive monetary rewards for their participation. MTurk workers who are located in the U.S., with a 95% HIT acceptance rate are eligible to participate. Before they can start the study, they must pass two screening questions to make sure they are not robots. One question requires basic human logic and common sense (e.g., up is to down as left is to ___?) and the other question is a Qualtrics Catcha. We will include an attention check and a comprehension check for the video prime in the study. Data from participants who fail either or both checks will be excluded from analyses. Any participants that have completed previous studies with be excluded with scripts, however we will check and remove any repeat MTurk IDs.

q14.value: Based on the results from our previous studies, a cell size of 150 is pre-determined.

q15.value: We will collect data until the sample size is met.

question.value: Video prime: participants watch a video either about income inequality in the US, or a neutral video about brain science.

Dependent variables: Participants report the following perceived values of both a genuine iPhone, and a counterfeit GooPhone: hednic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value. Additionally, egalitarian motives will be assessed using the con-trait dominance and con-trait antiegalitarianism items adapted from Ho et al., 2015, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, The Nature of Social Dominance Orientation, see Appendix A. Additional dependent variables: They reported the extent to which they would like to purchase the phone, and the dollar amount they are willing to pay for the phone. Potential covariates and moderators: They reported the extent to which they think counterfeit products are acceptable, prevalent, and easy to detect in their society. They reported individual difference in Social Dominance Orientation and socioeconomic status, as well as demographic variables.

All the scale measures with more than one item will be combined into an index by averaging the scores of all items in the scale. Before creating the index, we will first reversed code the items that are phrased reservedly. We will also test the reliability of the scale before creating the index. A chrombach's alpha = .7 is considered acceptable.

1) Separate ANOVAs on each of the dependent measures will be conducted, using the video prime as a factor. Simple t-tests will be used when no covariates (controls) are needed for analysis. We compute the difference score for each dependent variable between the iPhone and the GooPhone. 2) We will test parallel mediating effect of the different relative perceived values (hedonic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value) on the effect of video prime on purchase intention toward counterfeits. 3) We will test the serial mediating effect of perceived acceptance and prevalence of counterfeits on consumers' purchase intentions. 4) We will test the potential moderating effect of Social dominance orientation.

q20.value: Skewed dependent variables will be log transformed.

q21.value: p= .1 is marginally significant. p = .05 is significant. We will test simple effects of any interactions that are marginally significant.

q22.value: Data from participants who fail the attention check and the comprehension check will be excluded from analyses. Participants who have taken this or other related studies will be excluded.

q23.value: Participants with incomplete data will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value: We will test the moderating effect of perceived social acceptance and social prevalence of counterfeits, if they are not affected by the income inequality manipulation. We will test the moderating effect of social dominance orientation. We will test the moderating effect of socioeconomic status.

Any participants that have completed previous studies with be excluded with scripts, however we will check and remove any repeat MTurk IDs.
registration_responses.q16.question: Video prime: participants watch a video either about income inequality in the US, or a neutral video about brain science.
registration_responses.q17.question: Dependent variables: Participants report the following perceived values of both a genuine iPhone, and a counterfeit GooPhone: hednic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value. Additionally, egalitarian motives will be assessed using the con-trait dominance and con-trait antiegalitarianism items adapted from Ho et al., 2015, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, The Nature of Social Dominance Orientation, see Appendix A. Additional dependent variables: They reported the extent to which they would like to purchase the phone, and the dollar amount they are willing to pay for the phone. Potential covariates and moderators: They reported the extent to which they think counterfeit products are acceptable, prevalent, and easy to detect in their society. They reported individual difference in Social Dominance Orientation and socioeconomic status, as well as demographic variables.
registration_responses.q18.question: All the scale measures with more than one item will be combined into an index by averaging the scores of all items in the scale. Before creating the index, we will first reversed code the items that are phrased reservedly. We will also test the reliability of the scale before creating the index. A chrombach's alpha = .7 is considered acceptable.
registration_responses.q19.question: 1) Separate ANOVAs on each of the dependent measures will be conducted, using the video prime as a factor. Simple t-tests will be used when no covariates (controls) are needed for analysis. We compute the difference score for each dependent variable between the iPhone and the GooPhone. 2) We will test parallel mediating effect of the different relative perceived values (hedonic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value) on the effect of video prime on purchase intention toward counterfeits. 3) We will test the serial mediating effect of perceived acceptance and prevalence of counterfeits on consumers' purchase intentions. 4) We will test the potential moderating effect of Social dominance orientation.

attributes.title: Exploited or Empowered: Garment Industry work and women's political participation

q1.value: Exploited or Empowered: Garment Industry work and women's political participation

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Globalization has provided women workers in poor countries labor market opportunities, but has also introduced them to additional vulnerabilities, such as high job insecurity, and concerns about safety, sexual harassment and slave wages. While the economic opportunities connected with globalization have been studied extensively, few studies have addressed how globalization influences women’s political voice. They may participate more than other women workers to defend their economic gains or because they have greater resources. However, these workers are also particularly vulnerable to implicit or explicit pressures not to become politically active. This paper analyzes survey data from workers in the textile industry (the most globalized industry in the world and one in which more than 80% of workers are female) in India matched against survey data from female workers of similar socio-economic and educational backgrounds in the same city who work in domestic sector jobs. These two groups are equivalent in terms of culture, socialization, and other unobservable characteristics that drive differences in political behavior. This project uses observational survey data and two survey experiments to test whether working in the export industry changes the likelihood that workers will vote and whether they support lobbying or protest activities. Examining differences in political participation, interest, and knowledge reveals that globalization has significant and sometimes counterintuitive effects on women’s political participation.

q16.value: " There are competing expectations about the impact of work in this low-wage, low-skill exporting industry. The first predicts that workers will enjoy some benefits from work in an export industry and due to more earning power, greater social or economic resources, or a perception that politics are of higher salience to them because of their job these workers will be more politically engaged and report higher levels of participation. The other expectation focuses on the vulnerability of these workers relative to their employers and posits that due to the globalized nature of their job, their sense of job/economic risk is higher(because the workers are unskilled and easily replaced, job turnover is higher, global markets are more volatile, etc). Because of their vulnerability they have little bargaining power vis-a-vis their employer. In the face of direct pressure from employers to vote or behave a certain way or pressure from a family member not to ""rock the boat"" they eschew political participation (especially acts other than voting, such campaigning or protest). Even absent pressure to vote a certain way, because they feel or have been told that their political behavior might affect their industry (i.e., agitating for higher wages or better conditions will lead to lack of sales due to intense competition and that will lead to job loss), they will participate less than other women of similar socioeconomic status. "

q17.value: "The survey instruments collect a great deal of observational/reported data to help identify specific causal mechanisms. The survey experiments focus on two aspects of this. Participants are randomly assigned one of the following versions of a question about their likelihood to vote. If specific concerns about pressure from employers are more salient to workers in the garment industry, then the reported likelihood of voting should be different among the group for whom their employer is mentioned specifically. If increased earning power or increased risk changes these workers responsiveness to family pressures, then the likelihood of voting amid women receiving version two may differ from the control group. Survey Experiment 1 Version 1: When you go to vote, there are laws to make sure that your vote is completely secret. You vote in a screened compartment that keeps anyone from seeing how you vote and your choice is not seen by anyone, not other voters, polling officials, or election commission staff. Even if you cannot read or write, you can still vote in secret.Your employer cannot find out about which party or candidate you voted for. How likely do you think you are to vote in the next election? Version 2: When you go to vote, there are laws to make sure that your vote is completely secret. You vote in a screened compartment that keeps anyone from seeing how you vote and your choice is not seen by anyone, not other voters, polling officials, or election commission staff. Even if you cannot read or write, you can still vote in secret. No one in your family can find out about which party or candidate you voted for. How likely do you think you are to vote in the next election? Version 3: When you go to vote, there are laws to make sure that your vote is completely secret. You vote in a screened compartment that keeps anyone from seeing how you vote and your choice is not seen by anyone, not other voters, polling officials, or election commission staff. Even if you cannot read or write, you can still vote in secret. How likely do you think you are to vote in the next election? Version 4: How likely do you think you are to vote in the next election? The second survey experiment asks both about approval for petitioning the government and more extra-institutional political actions (protests and strikes) set against different frames that express different concerns: personal concerns for safety or wages versus larger concerns for the impact on the national economy or the industry job market. There is no explicit control version, however, workers outside the garment industry provide an important control group for the responses of workers in the garment industry. Survey experiment 2 Respondents were asked the following two questions, preceded by one of the frames listed below the questions. How much do you agree with the following statements: Workers in the garment industry and others like it should organize and, potentially, go on strikes or hold protest to demand higher wages and better working conditions (Strongly agree to Strongly Disagree, 5 point scale) Workers in the garment industry and others like it should lobby the government for laws that dictate better working conditions and/or better pay. (Strongly agree to Strongly Disagree, 5 point scale) Version 1: In 2013 a factory where workers sew clothing collapsed in Mumbai, killing at least one person, and injuring some people. Investigation revealed that there was unauthorized construction at the building. Version 2: The garment industry represents 14% of industrial activity and 17% of export income in India. It provides jobs for almost 35 million workers in India. It is vitally important to the overall economy of the country. Problems with workers could disrupt production in this industry. Version 3: Many international companies have workers in India sew clothing for them because it is less expensive for workers in India to make the clothing than for workers elsewhere to do it. If wages go up, some of these companies might have their clothing made in a different country. Version 4: The garment industry represents 14% of industrial activity and 17% of export income in India. It provides jobs for 35 million workers in India. The garment industry is vitally important to the overall economy of the country, but workers in the garment industry are paid little and work long hours in poor conditions."

attributes.title: Nationality on the Developing Community's Acceptance of NGOs

q1.value: Nationality on the Developing Community's Acceptance of NGOs

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: "When the British colonized Kenya in the early 20th century, they fiercely fought to eliminate female genital cutting (FGC), which they deemed as pagan. However, this practice had significant cultural and historical meaning to Kenyans, and foreign attempts at eradication often led to violence (Anderson 2005). Notwithstanding this local resistance, Western feminists entered Kenya in the 1950s and created non-government organizations (NGOs) aimed at wiping out FGC. These Western efforts proved fruitless, and it was not until African women themselves began speaking up against this cultural tradition that Kenyans became receptive to anti-FGC NGOs, resulting in the gradual waning of this practice (World Health Organization). Is local support a necessary condition for the success of NGOs that aim to eradicate practices deemed acceptable to local cultures, but that violate what Westerners view as universal human rights? Specifically, will NGOs fighting sex trafficking in Thailand be more efficacious with greater local representation in the NGOs? Knowing how local communities will respond to foreign NGOs is vital given that much of the developing world relies on huge amounts of foreign aid funneled into development-focused NGOs or supra-national foreign agencies (Easterly 2006). In addition, given the gendered bias of sex trafficking, to what extent does this local support rely on the involvement of women in NGOs? This second point may be especially problematic in countries where patriarchy is strong. To explore these questions, we will conduct an experiment in the northern Thailand this coming summer. Researchers in American politics have used experiments extensively to study how dimensions of identity, such as race and gender, affect perception of candidates and policy decisions (White 2007; Waismel-Manor & Stroud 2013). There have been few studies to date that explore such dynamics in non-Western contexts (Wantchekon 1999). Our research would add to this growing body of literature that explores how nationality affects perceptions of policies and organizations. We hope to improve the work of NGOs fighting against sex trafficking. Specifically, to understand the effect of NGO nationality and gender of NGO workers on receptivity of the NGO in local Thai communities."

q16.value: "Is local support a necessary condition for the success of NGOs that aim to eradicate practices deemed acceptable to local cultures, but that violate what Westerners view as universal human rights? Specifically, will NGOs fighting sex trafficking in Thailand be more efficacious with greater local representation in the NGOs?"

q17.value: "The exact language of the proposal will be developed through fieldwork, including personal interviews with actual NGOs and focus groups. Respondents will rate their favorability toward the NGO using a standard feeling thermometer. We will present the same proposal as a flyer on which we will place the face of an individual identified as an important person within the NGO’s, along with their name. Depending on complicity with local NGOs, we envision these being real individuals in a real anti-sex-trafficking NGO. We will vary the nationality and gender of the person shown in the picture. The person will be either a native Thai or a Caucasian American. We will also vary the gender of the person shown. In total, there will be four versions of the flyer: a female American, a male American, a female Thai, or a male Thai. We will randomly assign participants to view one of these four flyers. Before being exposed to the NGO flyer, all participants will take a pre-survey assessment that collects basic information such as gender, age, ethnicity, political ideology and level of education. We will use this information to study any kind of correlation between these covariates and our dependent variable. After conducting the experiment, we will use standard statistical techniques to assess our theory."

attributes.title: Patriotism and Perception of the Economy: Evidence from Russia

q1.value: Patriotism and Perception of the Economy: Evidence from Russia

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We study how patriotism and national identity affect the perception of economic performance. We are planning to run several survey experiments in Russia to examine whether patriotic feelings (1) improve individual's perception of past changes of his/her welfare and forecasts about the future performance of the economy, (2) change the reaction to news about the economy. In particular, negative news about the economy will make people more concerned about the economic policies issues and will make them support politicians less in the absence of patriotic feelings, but less so, when patriotism is present.

q16.value: "H1. Patriotism improves the perception of past changes in welfare. H2. Patriotism improves the perception of future changes in welfare. H3. Patriotism makes economic shocks less important, by switching attention to other policy aspects. H4. Patriotism reduces the reaction of support for politicians (Putin) to changes in economic conditions. H5. The effects in H1-H4 are concentrated among less informed, rural, poor population with pro-incumbent ideology and lower level of education (partially in line with Shayo, 2009)"

q17.value: "We will start with two phone survey experiments and then complement them with one online experiment. In Design 1A we will measure patriotism based on questions from World Value Survey and ISPP and then we will compare the answers to the questions about past and future perception of the economy across different groups in patriotism. In Design 1B we will prime people with patriotic issues and then study same outcomes as in 1A. The regression specification for Design 1 is Perception_i (Forecast_i)=a0+a1*Patriotism_i+e_i, where Patriotism_i is either survey measure of patriotism for individual i or patriotic priming of individual i (randomized). H1&H2 imply a1>0. Design 2 suggests to cross-randomize patriotic priming and information about the economy (negative news about inflation) and then study how people rank importance of policy priorities (economic policies vs external affairs) and how they support politicians. Denoting by T_i randomly provided information about negative economic news and by Patriotism_i -- patriotic priming, the regressions of interest for design 2 are Rank of economic issues_i=b0+b1*T_i+b2*Patriotism_i+b3*Patriotism_i*T_i+u_i, Support for Putin_i=c0+c1*T_i+c2*Patriotism_i+c3*Patriotism_i*T_i+u_i. Where H3 implies b10, b1+b3>0, so economic policies become relatively more important with negative news, but less so with high levels of patriotism. For sufficiently high levels of patriotism they become less important. Similarly, H4 implies c10, c3+c1>0. People support incumbent politicians (Putin) less, when they receive negative news about the economy, but less so for high levels of patriotism. For high level of patriotism negative shocks can actually increase the support. For H5 we will look on a set of interaction terms with income, education, dummy for rural population and such measure of access to information as internet availability."

attributes.title: Consensus: How the Mean and Variance of Perceived Traits Interact to Predict Outcomes

q1.value: Effect of dominance on binary bouncer hiring judgments

q3.value: Participants will rate 100 randomly selected pictures (out of 115 total pictures) from the Bogazici Face Database. For each face, they will indicate whether they would "hire this person as a bouncer at a bar" as a Yes/No response. Then, they will provide demographics and receive debriefing.

q4.value:
We will aggregate participants' responses to create a "proportion of Yes responses" variable for each of the 115 faces. Then, we will fit a model predicting this variable as a function of faces' mean dominance ratings (provided in the codebook), standard deviation in dominance ratings (provided in the codebook), and their interaction.

Our key prediction is that the interaction between mean dominance  and standard deviation in dominance  will be significant, such that standard deviation in dominance will more positively predict the proportion of "Yes" responses as mean dominance decreases.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We are collecting participant ratings in order to stably estimate proportion scores for "being hired as a bouncer" for each of 115 face stimuli. Participants will each rate 100 randomly sampled stimuli.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Our predictors, mean dominance and standard deviation in dominance, already exist in the Bogazici Face Database codebook. However, our outcome variable has not yet been created, and no analogous outcomes variables currently exist.

question.value: We will collect data from 45 human participants from MTurk. Participants recruited from the United States and Canada will receive 70 cents for completing the study. Other than an MTurk worker rating of 95 or higher, no selection criteria are used. The study takes approximately 7 minutes to complete.

q14.value: ~40 participant ratings per stimulus face is sufficient to achieve a stable estimate of each face's "proportion of Yes responses" variable.

question.value: For each face, we will measure whether participants would "hire this person as a bouncer at a bar".

We will fit a regression in R:

model <- lm(prop_hire ~ mean_dominance*sd_dominance, data=data)

q22.value: We will conduct sensitivity analyses excluding photographs with high SDs (3+). Before calculating proportion scores for each photograph, we will exclude participants' responses that have a latency of < 400ms and those that repeated the same response for 90% or more trials (i.e., pressed the same button over and over).
